text: The only way to do great work is to love what you do.
author: Steve Jobs
description: A reminder that passion fuels excellence in our work.
story:
In 1985, Steve Jobs was forced out of Apple, the company he co-founded. Most people would have seen this as a devastating failure. But Jobs didn't retreat. Instead, he founded NeXT and Pixar, companies that would later revolutionize computing and animation.

During this period, Jobs often reflected on what drove him. It wasn't money or fame—he already had both. It was the pure joy of creating something meaningful. He would spend hours obsessing over the smallest details, from the curve of a computer case to the sound a laptop makes when it closes.

When Jobs returned to Apple in 1997, the company was weeks from bankruptcy. But his passion reignited the team. He didn't just want to make products; he wanted to make products people would love. This obsession led to the iMac, iPod, iPhone, and iPad.

The lesson isn't about being a genius—it's about finding work that energizes you so much that the long hours don't feel like work. Jobs famously said he never worked a day in his life because he loved what he did. That's the difference between a job and a calling.

Today, ask yourself: Does your work excite you? If not, what small step can you take toward finding that passion? It might not happen overnight, but every great journey begins with a single step toward what you love.

text: Innovation distinguishes between a leader and a follower.
author: Steve Jobs
description: True leaders create new paths rather than following existing ones.
story:
In 2007, the mobile phone industry was dominated by Nokia and BlackBerry. They had the market figured out: physical keyboards, email integration, and enterprise features. Everyone was following the same playbook.

Then Steve Jobs walked onto a stage and held up the iPhone. No keyboard. No stylus. Just a screen. Industry experts laughed. 'It'll never work,' they said. 'People need physical buttons.' BlackBerry's CEO famously dismissed it as a toy.

But Jobs wasn't trying to make a better phone—he was reimagining what a phone could be. He saw a future where your phone was a camera, music player, web browser, and communication device all in one. He didn't ask customers what they wanted; he showed them what they didn't know they needed.

Within five years, Nokia and BlackBerry were struggling to survive. The iPhone had redefined an entire industry. Jobs didn't follow the market—he created it.

This is the essence of leadership through innovation. Followers improve what exists. Leaders imagine what could exist. They take risks when others play it safe. They ask 'what if?' when others say 'that's how it's always been done.'

You don't need to invent the next iPhone to be innovative. Innovation starts with questioning assumptions. What's one thing in your field that everyone accepts as 'the way things are'? What if you challenged it? That's where breakthrough begins.

text: Life is what happens when you're busy making other plans.
author: John Lennon
description: A perspective on embracing the present moment instead of over-planning.
story:
John Lennon wrote this line in 1980 for the song 'Beautiful Boy,' a letter to his five-year-old son Sean. At the time, Lennon had stepped away from music for five years to be a full-time father—a decision that shocked the world.

Here was one of the most famous musicians alive, choosing diapers over stadiums. Friends and managers told him he was throwing away his career. But Lennon had learned something that many of us take decades to understand: the plans we obsess over often matter less than the moments we're living through.

Lennon spent those years baking bread, taking Sean to the park, and simply being present. He later said those were the best years of his life—not the Beatles years, not the chart-topping hits, but the quiet mornings with his son.

Tragically, Lennon was killed just months after writing that song. He never got to see Sean grow up. But his words lived on as a reminder: we can't control the future, and our carefully laid plans often crumble. What we can control is whether we're truly present for the life happening right now.

How many moments have you missed while worrying about tomorrow? How many conversations have you been physically present for but mentally absent? Lennon's wisdom is simple but profound: stop planning long enough to actually live.

Today, try this: put down your phone during one meal. Have one conversation where you're fully present. Take one walk without a destination. Life isn't waiting for you to finish your to-do list—it's happening right now.
